awd_titl_txt: Framework: Software: Collaborative Research: CyberWater-An open and sustainable framework for diverse data and model integration with provenance and access to HPC
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses a high priority need for water research communities: interoperability among a wide variety of data sources and models, and integration of different computational models into water research communities.  The project will develop an open and sustainable software framework enabling integration of hydrologic data and models for interdisciplinary teamwork and discovery.   The models and datasets cover fields such as hydrology, biology, environmental engineering and climate.  The project also addresses one of the key issues for extreme-scale computing:  scalable file systems.  The collaboration draws upon computing, modeling, and hydrology expertise at six institutions: University of Pittsburgh, University of Iowa, Ball State University, North Carolina State University, Indiana University, and the Consortium of Universities for the Advancement of Hydrologic Science, Inc. (CUAHSI).  

The project develops CyberWater, a community-driven software framework that integrates a wide range of models and datasets across disparate temporal and spatial scales. The CyberWater framework allows scientists to bypass challenges associated with model and dataset complexity.  The project designs a model agent tool enabling users to generate model agents for common model types without coding, and integrates multiple existing software codes/elements that provide for broad-scale use.  To develop such a diverse modeling framework, the project brings together hydrologists, climate experts, meteorologists, computer scientists and cyberinfrastructure experts.  The project builds upon an existing prototype developed by the lead investigator;  basic elements for the system were developed, consisting of plugged-in models and data sources with corresponding agents and a workflow engine allowing user workflow control.  The prototype was successfully demonstrated for two models, making use of datasets plugged in from NASA, USGS and CUAHSI.  For the current project, new models and datasets are added to the framework; the ability to use high performance computing resources is also incorporated.  The team will use the CUAHSI HydroShare System to distribute CyberWater software and its associate model agents, including instructions on how to establish a local CyberWater environment, models and model agents. The project will enable substantial scientific advances for water related issues, and the solution can be applied to other research disciplines. 

This award by the Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure is jointly supported by the NSF Directorate for Geosciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project built an open data, open modeling framework to expedite the process for knowledge discoveries and reduce the time and effort for users to build integrated hydrology models. The primary project deliverable, CyberWater, was created to support building composable scientific models. Through this work a generalized mechanism was developed to bring together a diverse array of data sources and scientific models, for use in research, education, model testing and evaluation, results validations, and model inter-comparisons, in a fully descriptive and replicable manner. The work completed on this cooperative grant led by researchers at the Consortium of Universities for the Advancement of Hydrologic Sciences Inc (CUAHSI), focused primarily on disseminating the CyberWater modeling framework to the hydrology community, presenting science use cases, and collecting feedback that was used to inform project priorities and deliverables. 


Over the course of the project, four community workshop events were coordinated to share project progress with the hydrologic science community, all of which were held virtually. While the goals of each event varied, each consisted of several modeling use cases that were completed by event participants at their own pace. Assistance was provided via virtual office hours and each event completed with a workshop debrief and feedback survey to identify strengths and weaknesses of the CyberWater modeling framework. Through these workshops, we found that the CyberWater platform offers an intuitive user interface for building scientific model configurations that has potential to be used in education, research, and science dissemination applications. Some of the challenges that were identified include building complex model configurations and a general shortage of appropriate tools for complex data visualization of model outputs and validation. These surveys identified areas to extend efforts such as providing connections to additional scientific data sources, improved documentation, model validation and calibration capabilities, and diagnostic tools. This effort supported the project goal of engaging the community by soliciting feedback from early-career researchers that both informed project deliverables and established a foundation onto which a CyberWater user?s community can be fostered.


Additional capabilities were developed to support the execution of the WRF-Hydro modeling system within the CyberWater (Windows) framework. Since this model and the necessary supporting tools are designed to run on Linux operating systems, software containerization technologies were leveraged to enable execution on Windows. Adding support for software containerization, using Docker, in conjunction with existing CyberWater capabilities provided a mechanism for users to easily include any hydrologic model into the CyberWater framework regardless of operating system. This was the feature of the final workshop, led by CUAHSI, which explored the utility of using CyberWater for computationally intensive hydrologic modeling applications using WRF-Hydro. Feedback received from this event indicates a general interest in the software containerization approach, however additional work is necessary to simplify the process for community-wide use.  This effort directly supported the project goal of expediting fundamental knowledge discoveries by extending CyberWater?s support for a wide variety of legacy scientific models that have been designed for Linux operating systems.


This project has established a modeling framework to effectively support communication among diverse computational models in a graphical workflow environment which significantly reduces the current complexity of model integration. Through active engagement with the hydrology community, scientists have begun to use CyberWater to create modeling workflows that greatly simplify data access, model studies and model coupling, reproducible computing, and provide easy access to HPC resources. Not only do project deliverables significantly enhance productivity and efficacy of scientific research, their generic design can be adapted and extended to other scientific and engineering disciplines.
